newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai stocks end at 40-month low on foreign sales.
newsitem.headline: Thai stocks end at 40-month low on foreign sales.

text.p: Thai stocks ended at their lowest level in 40 months as foreigners sold out and fears grew of a major foreign exodus from the bourse, traders said.
The SET Index shed 7.49 points, or 0.83 percent, to close below the key 900-point level at 898.32, on trade worth 3.53 billion baht. The SET-50 closed down 0.55 points to 68.00.
The previous lowest close was at 893.14 on July 27, 1993.

"The first worry is the government's ability to deal with the economy but the other is that people are worried foreign mutual funds might leave the market," said an analyst at Pacific Finance and Securities.
"They mostly sold banks ... one reason is economics the other is the policies the government has to improve the economy," he said.
Thailand is set to post economic growth of under 7.00 percent this year, its lowest for a decade, while carrying a current account deficit of around 8.00 percent of GDP.
"The positions the foreigners took prior to the election are being unwoumd now. They have been net sellers for months now," said another senior analyst.
Siam Commercial Bank lost four baht to 188, Thai Farmers shed three baht to 135 and Siam Cement dipped 12 to 832.
